title: How to Help Protect a Senior's Finances
summary: According to a 2009 study by the National Institute of Justice, 5% of Americans age 60 and older have been victims of financial abuse by a family member and 6.5% were the target of a non-family member. Meanwhile, a 2011 report by insurer MetLife estimates that financial fraud, including telemarketing fraud, cost the elderly nearly $3 billion a year.

tag-4: Some of these changes may be legitimate. For instance, that new person working with the senior may be an attorney, accountant or financial advisor. Still, as a precaution, consider a background check.
tag-5: You should also do background checks, including criminal checks, on any caregivers, as well as the agency that may have referred them. If seniors don't already have it, suggest they get caller ID for their phone, so they can screen out telemarketers. Finally, if the older person will agree, have duplicate financial statements sent to a trusted family member or professional advisor who can look for any unusual transactions.
